description: A merger of two verbs of similar form and meaning:

verbs.description: wake (third-person singular simple present wakes, present participle waking, simple past woke or waked, past participle woken or waked or (now colloquial) woke)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) (often followed by up) To stop sleeping.
examples: I woke up at four o'clock this morning.

entries.meaning: (transitive) (often followed by up) To make somebody stop sleeping; to rouse from sleep.
examples: The neighbour's car alarm woke me from a strange dream.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To put in motion or action; to arouse; to excite.
examples: Even Richard's crusade woke little interest in his island realm.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To be excited or roused up; to be stirred up from a dormant, torpid, or inactive state; to be active.
To watch, or sit up with, at night, as a dead body.
To be or remain awake; not to sleep.
examples: I cannot think any time, waking or sleeping, without being sensible of it.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To be alert; to keep watch
examples: Command unto the guards that they diligently wake.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To sit up late for festive purposes; to hold a night revel.

description: From Middle English wake, from Old English wacu, from Proto-Germanic *wakō.

entries.meaning: (often obsolete or poetic) The act of waking, or state of being awake.
examples: Singing her flatteries to my morning wake.

entries.meaning: The state of forbearing sleep, especially for solemn or festive purposes; a vigil.
examples: The warlike wakes continued all the night,  And funeral games played at new returning light.

entries.meaning: A period after a person's death before or after the body is buried, cremated, etc.; in some cultures accompanied by a party and/or collectively sorting through the deceased's personal effects.
examples: Where any person has died whilst being, or suspected of being, a case or carrier or contact of an infectious disease, the Director may by order prohibit the conduct of a wake over the body of that person or impose such conditions as he thinks fit on the conduct of such wake  […]

entries.meaning: (historical, Church of England) A yearly parish festival formerly held in commemoration of the dedication of a church. Originally, prayers were said on the evening preceding, and hymns were sung during the night, in the church; subsequently, these vigils were discontinued, and the day itself, often with succeeding days, was occupied in rural pastimes and exercises, attended by eating and drinking.
examples: Great solemnities were made in all churches, and great fairs and wakes throughout all England.

entries.meaning: A number of vultures assembled together.

description: Probably from Middle Low German or Middle Dutch wake, from or akin to Old Norse vǫk (“a hole in the ice”) ( > Danish våge, Icelandic vök), from Proto-Germanic *wakwō (“wetness”), from Proto-Indo-European *wegʷ- (“moist, wet”).

entries.meaning: (nautical) The path left behind a ship on the surface of the water.
The movement of water created when an animal or a person moves through water.
(aviation) The turbulent air left behind a flying aircraft.
(figuratively) The area behind something, typically a rapidly-moving object.
examples: This effect followed immediately in the wake of his earliest exertions.
